ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were also pre-recorded lectures to watch before class sessions.
The professor also brought in guest speakers virtually.
Dr. Fauci Webinar
Had guest speakers, lectures, and discussion.
Some pre-recorded lectures were involved that were to be watched prior to the day's Zoom sessions
Sessions had to be attended live, but there were some lectures that had to be watched prior to attending the live session.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about covid-19 and a few other current public health issues. I also learned how to read lots of scholarly articles and other works.
I learned to read and summarize scientific studies and to write about them. I also learned to write short articles in news style, as well as how to talk about scientific findings.

We were given the opportunity to write articles (both collaboratively and individually) on topics of our choosing. Article-writing helped me develop the skills necessary for writing briefly and concisely on a topic, highlighting the most pertinent information. We also wrote two papers that required more research and allowed us to go more in-depth in a topic of our choice.

I learned a lot about the COVID-19 pandemic and other public health issues, like smoking, genetic counseling, and cancer screenings. I also learned how to efficiently read scientific papers and write my own academic-style papers.
This course helped me developed my skills in communicating large ideas or niche concepts into something more digestible to a general audience.
I learned how to find and recognize credible information regarding scientific topics. I also learned how to interpret it at a higher level.
I was able to develop my discussion skills and learn about covid and current medical issues.
Insight on a variety of aspects of public health as well as many past controversies surrounding it and media portrayal of it.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really liked how we were assigned to read pieces from lots of different news sources and scholarly journals. I think the course could've been varied a bit in what we did most days because we had the same kind of discussions pretty frequently.

The strengths of this class are the discussion style format and the writing we did which I felt I learned a lot from. A weakness would be that the canvas page was a bit difficult to navigate with assignments and discussion posts not lining up. Sometimes it was unclear when readings were due/ assigned.

Strengths: The professor selected very good readings/films/lectures for us to watch. We also had good discussions; I like how the professor put us into breakout rooms to discuss topics with smaller groups. 
Weaknesses: It would have been nice to get some more guidance on the papers. It was definitely useful and relevant to discuss COVID-19, but the class might have been more engaging if we had discussed more public health issues/topics.
I loved the way the class was run and think that Prof. Bazell is a great instructor. I dont think the course could have been improved
I loved the way this class was. There were a lot of discussions and lots of engagement. Posting clearly what the grades were after each assignment would have been helpful.

The course is highly engaging and interesting as the material covered in class is highly relevant to the current times. Additionally, the course focuses on a broad range of topics that are surprisingly linked to public health, which keeps things interesting as things don't get too redundant.

The course had a good format consisting of discussions after individual reading of material in most classes. In some classes the professor jumped in and lectures and in others we had a guest speaker. The only suggestion I have is that I wish that the professor lectured more in class as I found that method the most captivating and I grasped the most when he did that.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I am glad we were able to have some incredible experts come on and speak to us and feel lucky that it was still possible to do that during the pandemic. I also think the use of the breakout room function throughout class used effectively well too.
I think we still managed to have good discussions and even had speaker events in class over Zoom, so it fared pretty well.

Part of our homework assignments was posting questions or topics on Canvas that would inform our discussion for the following class, which held us all accountable for doing the work for this course. It also kept me engaged during class and while doing the homework.

I like how the professor placed us into breakout rooms to discuss topics. It helped us get to know other students in the class, which is otherwise difficult over Zoom. I also really appreciate how he brought in guest speakers who are experts in their field. The structure of the class was very similar most of the time go into breakout rooms, discuss, reconvene in the larger group. It could've been more engaging if we switched up the structure a bit.
The breakout rooms to prepare for group discussions in this class were very useful and often very productive. Some of the readings were redundant but that is all
The discussions and breakout rooms were a success as well as the group assignments. I dont think anything needs to be approved other than posting our grades to canvas.

I believe that there was a lot of extra opportunity in terms of having guest speakers who were extremely knowledgable in certain fields (like genetics) because of the virtual format and the course adapted well in that regard.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student. This year more than ever I think it is a super interesting class that anyone would enjoy because it is so current with the state of the pandemic. I'm jealous of those who will take the course in the Spring and get to learn more and talk about the state of the vaccine!
I would recommend this course to another student. I thought it was very interesting and engaging. The speakers especially were very great. Prof Bazell is really knowledgeable and engaging.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student who's interested in public health topics. The professor is great and the readings are interesting and relevant.

Yes. It was a great course that is super interesting due to its insight that it gives into public health. Prof. Bazell is an amazing instructor and clears up any misunderstanding that may have occurred in the reading
I definitely would. The course was engaging and thought provoking. I loved getting to know the other students as well as learning about the current pandemic.

I would definitely recommend this course to another Yale First-Year student. The course content is highly relevant to the current state of the world. Additionally, for students interested in entering a health-related field, this is an engaging first-year seminar that allows you to delve deeper into public health and realize that its scope is much greater than just modern medicine.
This course was very interesting and offers a lot for those who are interested in medicine or public health. I would definitely recommend it to them.
